text: (light music)
- At the onset of the pandemic,
Johns Hopkins was trying to figure out how
to mitigate the problems associated
with the spread of disease.

It's difficult to simulate
real life at the scale
that we wanted to create.

We were looking for a platform
to assist us with our work
and really allow us

to achieve our goals in
simulating communities.

AWS SimSpace Weaver is a
computational accelerator
for simulations like ours,
and it's really built to be streamlined.

So that in fact, my students,
they're very talented,

but they found that this is
an easy platform to work with.

- We scale our simulations
from 10,000 to 240,000,
which we can't really imagine that before.

The whole process working
with AWS is really comfortable

and they're really supportive,
which makes our project easy
to get to the point we are here.

- What we want to do is take
these examples to learn lessons

from the scale of communities
that we're looking at now,

because we can start to look
at individual facilities
that may need to be looked at

as a potential vulnerable
place that needs to be managed
as opposed to looking at all places

and having a one-size-fits-all
kind of policy.
So having that scale to make it realistic

so that decision-makers
can look at their community

and be able to identify
where there are things

that can be improved to
reduce the impact of diseases,
that's really critical.

And that can make a big difference,
really across the world,
for people to be able
to not only manage what's going on now,
but prepare for future pandemics.
(light music)
